timeline.message: Merge branch 'ja_20200423_multitenancy_2' of github.com:jamesagnew/hapi-fhir into ja_20200423_multitenancy_2
Merge branch 'ja_20200423_multitenancy_2' of github.com:jamesagnew/hapi-fhir into ja_20200423_multitenancy_2

timeline.bodyText: I think this is a kind of request, not a kind of partition id, so I'd go with "PartitionIdRequest".
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: Hmmm this is fun. TBH I kind of feel the opposite.. It's a "request partition ID", meaning the partition ID for a request. PartitionIdRequest sounds to me more like it's a request FOR a partition ID, which is the opposite of what it is really..... I don't know, I don't know...
replies.author: jamesagnew

replies.bodyText: oh funny when I initially suggested adding "Request" to the name, I wasn't thinking of it in in the http request sense, but more like "I'm asking for a partition id".  Because the answer could come back, "no such partition exists" which would be a failed outcome on that request.  But I see it's confusing because Request already means something in the framework.
replies.author: fil512

timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: Fair enough, have changed it
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            	 * key will be of type {@link ca.uhn.fhir.interceptor.model.PersistedPartitionId}.
          
          
            
            	 * key will be of type {@link ca.uhn.fhir.interceptor.model.RequestPartitionId}.
timeline.author: fil512

+	 * key will be of type {@link ca.uhn.fhir.interceptor.model.PersistedPartitionId}.

replies.bodyText: I am surprised IJ didn't auto fix that when I refactored.... Weird.

timeline.bodyText: rather than static, why not make it an instance method?  (default method since it's an interface)
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: I thought about that, but the whole point is that it can accept null.. If it was an instance method it could not do that
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: This looks risky.  What if I have a tenantId that is the same name as a legit path?  Is there some other way in the request we can track whether the tenandId has been appended?  (e.g. in a custom header)
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: Hmm... Thinking on this now
replies.author: jamesagnew

replies.bodyText: Ok, figured out a way to track where the URL actually came from.. If it came from the outside world as opposed to being generated, we won't tweak it

timeline.bodyText: Nice.  This is a really elegant way to manage this cache.
timeline.author: fil512

timeline.bodyText: Nice you got rid of a meaningful null.

replies.bodyText: Yeah I had this nagging feeling (guess it was a code smell) that this would lead to subtle bugs eventually....
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: nitpick: Replace numbered comments with methods
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: Agree in general, but don't want to refaxctor this existing method right now
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: How do you decide if a class is a Service or a Svc?
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText:
Or just a Helper?
I've been using Helper for instance helpers and Util for static helpers.
replies.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: GUess it should be Svc based on today's conversation
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: I know it's probably too late for this comment, but seeing this code here makes me wonder: are there pieces of the partition filter that could be implemented as a consent interceptor?  (clearly when it's a predicate added to a query this doesn't make sense--but there are parts of the code like this where it's not a part of the query and might be more clearly expressed as a consent interceptor...?)
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: The problem with the consent interceptor is that it is applied to resources -after- the SQL query has taken place, so it's really intended for stuations where you expect the majority of resources to not be filtered out...That is an issue with the way consent interceptor works right now, but I think it makes it not a great place for this logic
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: Never used.  If this is called to build the cache, maybe don't store the results?
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: @fil512 I'm not sure I follow this comment
replies.author: jamesagnew

replies.bodyText: IntelliJ twas telling me that the pidToForcedId variable is never used.  So I'm suggesting either delete the line, or if the call to translatePidsToForcedIds() is important because it's building a cache, then call it but don't store the return value.
replies.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: Ah ok.. refactored.

timeline.bodyText: Good call.  I fell victim to "Gosh this is so cool" syndrome here.
